ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my understanding of calculus so much! It's incredible how much information I learned in just a semester. We mostly dealt with mathematical reasoning and proofs with some room for development in terms of applying the math.

Honestly, I feel like I didnt learn much from the course itself. I often felt confused or lost during lecture. I feel like the lectures combined with the homework didnt properly prepare me for any of the tests.

calculus 1 (fundamental theorem of calculus, derivatives, limits and continuity, derivative rules, applications of derivatives, definite and indefinite integrals, riemann sums, differential equations, etc.)
This course provides a thorough understanding of calculus 1. It also pushes you to develop quantitative reasoning skills and think differently about math and learn in a new way

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: this course provided many opportunities to practice what we learned--however, I think it didn't allow for enough TIME to develop and allow students to absorb these concepts. 

Weaknesses: PEER TUTORING OFFICE HOURS! I cannot stress this enough but there were not enough peer tutors to support the overwhelming number of students who needed help. In addition, group coaching was not a resource I was made aware of early enough to meaningfully impact my grade. It helped me understand concepts to a deeper level, but by the time I got the help I needed, the semester was basically over. I think these resources we have should be made more visible earlier on.

strengths: gained a thorough introduction to calculus that is necessary for my major, ximera was helpful
weaknesses: the psets are worth a small percentage of our final grade yet we spend so much time during the week working on them (in my opinion, they should either be worth more of our final grade or there should be less/shorter psets)

There is plenty of help if you are struggling with anything. The topics are pretty interesting as you are able to see how many of the formulas are derived and how they apply to real life. Topics are adequately explained, and I found the online tutorials very useful.

Strengths: lots of support available in the form of office hours and review sessions
Weaknesses: sometimes topics felt like they were taught in a roundabout way/more complicated than the topic actually is, had to look for other resources to learn from

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but be prepared to be very, very diligent about your learning.

Not unless they are required to. This course was more work than it was worth. I feel like the Psets were too much seeing as they were way harder than the tests and took too much time. You also dont learn anything in lecture so you have to self teach.
Yes, I learned calculus and can say that I am better at it now.
yes, recommended to those that need to take calculus as a prerequisite for their major. also for those that want to complete their QR credit.
Yes, it helps you to be able to calculate the area under the graph.
Yes, it goes over the basics of calculus which you need to continue into other math classes. Also helps you to assimilate to the teaching style at Yale and how you are expected to learn math in-depth
